hobby.message: Origami helping you dodge the spiral?
I hear analog photography still survives in your hands.

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I explore the city's underground. It's a different world down there.
neutral_answer: Just passing through. Needed a bit of quiet.
I mess around with old tunnels sometimes. Keeps me busy.
With all the recent chaos, I can go further than usual.
Still, I keep things simple. You never know who’s listening.
Needed a break after exploring for a few hours underground.
Urban exploration’s my hobby. Utility tunnels, old substations, that sort of thing.
Lot easier with BCI down lately, less eyes in the dark.
Still don’t trust it’ll last, but I make the most of it.
Only go where I know I won’t get noticed.
Relaxing after a night crawling through the coolant tunnels. It’s my thing.
I like the forgotten parts of the city. Data centers, unused maintenance shafts.
Normally BCI gets in my way, low score and all.
Last week, everything opened up. No scans, no gates.
Ran into other explorers for once, didn’t have to hide it.
Nice change, though not sure it’ll stick.
I wind down here after a good urban crawl. Utility tunnels are home turf.
Been mapping old fiber routes. Place is full of secrets, if you know where to look.
BCI lockdowns used to block me out everywhere. My score’s a running joke.
Funny thing—since the system glitched, I’ve gone places I used to only dream about.
Ran into some students poking around the same shafts. Felt like the old days.
We even shared routes. Beats hiding from sensors every two minutes.
Still not sure if I trust how open things are, but can’t resist exploring now.
Urban exploration. Not the tourist kind, the guts of the city. Been at it twenty years.
I used to handle sys maintenance before things got locked down by Halden and his crew.
Once BCI pegged me as trouble, every hatch and door became a gamble.
Strange week—when the score checks vanished, saw locked gates just swing open.
First time in years, ran into other regulars underground. No one ran, no alarms.
Some of us traded flask shots in an old cooling pit, swapping tips and stories.
Funny—almost made me feel like a real citizen again. Not just a tolerated fault.
Whole system’s upside down, but underground? Peace of mind’s making a comeback.
hobby_answer: Yeah, found a few ghosts. Still plenty of empty tunnels.
Been quieter since the BCI blackout. Easier, sort of.
Not really taking chances, though. System's unstable.
People poke around more now, but I keep my distance.
Never trust an empty corridor these days.
Yeah, seen ghosts. More folks turn up in tunnels now.
With the BCI off, fewer locks, more surprises.
Still watch my back. Directorate types aren’t gone.
Last week I dodged two kids mapping vents. Bold move lately.
Not sure how long this 'score-blindness' will last.
Can't let my guard down, not in Stenograd.
Yeah, found a couple. The tunnels are getting busy these days.
Since the BCI glitch, access is easy—doors just don’t check for scores now.
Met some curious types down there, didn’t expect company.
People explore more without the old score paranoia.
Still, you feel that tension. City’s off balance, even under the street.
I’m making paper notes again, in case things swing back.
Kind of miss being the only one risking it, honestly.
Sure did. BCI blackout means everyone tries to explore now, not just us regulars.
It’s wild—doors wide open, sensors blank. Like the old systems are just asleep.
I walked all the way to the South pumps last weekend. Never got stopped once.
Saw old “disappeared” faces, people the system erased.
Honestly, it’s got a strange energy. Feels like old Stenograd before the Index.
Folks are reconnecting, swapping old maps, forming new little crews.
Bit of a headache, but more alive down there than I’ve seen in years.
Guess freedom’s loud, even if it’s shaky.
Yeah, ghosts and all. Tunnels feel like home again since the system glitched.
BCI blackout cleared my path. Finally walked old routes without scanning my badge every step.
Met kids, old-timers, even people who’d vanished when their scores tanked.
We shared old diagrams, fixed busted lights, swapped real stories for once.
Last week someone brewed a batch by the service tanks. Never would’ve risked it before.
I feel the old thrill again—city’s alive, unpredictable, and less policed.
Of course, Directorate’s still sniffing, but folks stand their ground now.
I keep hard copies of maps, just in case. Don’t trust memory or code lately.
Funny—without scores in charge, people seem more human, even under concrete.
